text: Red currant nose. Hazy tea, thin head. Currant and funk. Light body, soft carbonation, nicely tart, absolutely no alcohol detected.

Tap. Foamy light tan head, ruby murky brown. Sour dark cherries, oak, light toffee, some mineral, and dark sweet grapes in the aroma and a soft balsamic sourness. Flavor is sour but really well balanced, oaky and a touch dry, sour dark cherries again and a bit vinous. Lighter body with tight carbonation. Nice.

Bottle shared at the July 2016 MDBG tasting, 7/11/16. Batch 22. Hazy rust, thin fizzy tan head, good retention. Aroma of oak, caramel, funk, cherries, vanilla. The taste is caramel, vanilla, funk, brett, oak. Medium bodied, well balanced.

375 ml bottle. Batch No 2015.
Pours dark mahogany color with a small head. Aroma is moderately sour with ripe fruits and dark berries, some yeast and wood. Flavor is dry and woody, some malts, dark berries, sour apricot and yeast. A bit mellow with my high expectations, decent anyway.

Bottle 0.375l at Laitis, Helsinki. Thanks to Jow! Batch #2015. Colour is reddish light brown with very small white head. Aromas and flavors: Berries, some tartness, some sourness and dryness. Very nice juicy berries but needs maybe little bit of sourness and tartness.

37,5 cl bottle @ home. 
Aroma has tart berry juice and some currants. Flavour is tart with sour berry juice and milky tones. Also wood, mild balsamico tones and red wine. Perky and aggressive but not my thing exactly.

375ml bottle, 2015 vintage. Pours deep reddish with a tiny white head. Aroma of sour berries, wood, oak, bretta, vinous notes and tartness. Taste is tartish, oaky and woody with some bretta, sourish vinous berries, toffee and grapes. Finish is smooth, slightly tart and sourish with hints of oak, wood, berries and vinous notes. Not very intense, but quite balanced vinous sour ale.

375 ml bottle. Pours a dark amber brown colour without a head. Aroma of strong green apples, vinegar, some chocolate and wood. Flavour of strong vinegar notes, green apples, red berries, a bit of toasted malts and graininess. Some wood. Medium bodied. Good.

UPDATED: JUN 11, 2016 Draft at Monks. Very hazy copper pour. No head. Full-flavored sour with tons of rich complex dark red grape tannins. Plums and prunes. Chestnuts. Raspberries. Blueberries. Acai berries. Bing cherries. Wild strawberry caramel in the middle but a very dry finish.

Bottle thanks to Rainer. Pours a cloudy copper brown with small off white head that lasts. The aroma is strong oak, funk, brett, grape. Thin mouth, funky, grape, oak tannin, light tartness, very nice.

For Cinco de Mayo! Batch No 2015, corked and caged, 12.7 fl oz, no idea about alcohol level. Unavoidably extreme and terrible gusher, probably lost about a quarter to the floor, resulting hazy chestnut beer in the glass incredibly carbonated, agitated like a shaken nest of hornets long after the brief tan head fizzed itself out. Nose potent Brett, grape with huge cherry and raisin, sharp acidity, very heavy wood, some mild lactone but more woodsy and decaying leaves overall. Bracing acidity puckers right off the bat and it has that element that amplifies the bitterness to medium-strong; its not an IPA-like bitterness, cleaner and closer to scratchy tannins than hop derivatives. Tremendous fruitiness married perfectly to the sourness, a really fresh, bright edge on top. Little bit of lemon/citrus along with the balanced but deep and complex brown malt. Nice mix of lactic and acetic, the latter reserved enough that I cant readily use my favorite balsamic deScriptor; medium body with a milky and lightly burning finish. Still no idea about alcohol. I really like the grape variety they used, neither jammy nor foxy, but elegant and warm; the tannins and wood lend tremendous structure to what would otherwise be an over-aggressive loudmouth (though Im sure someones calling this a "wood bomb"). World class, right here. [2016.05.05: 4.3]

Dégustée en compagnie de Marc-André et Yan. Après une verticale de 4 ans de KBS, rien de mieux pour se rincer le palais quune jolie sour BA! Un look léger et intelligent. Le liquide est mi rouge mi rose, dépourvu de toute mousse. Les arômes qui me parviennent sont celles dun baril affirmé ayant longtemps servi de résidence à un funk plein de vie sétant empiffré de raisin rouge. Aucun alcool mais un vinaigre qui laisse présager une acidité sans merci. Aucune surprise ici, le liquide est dune acidité tranchante et sadresse aux palais exercés. Malgré cette agressivité, la buvabilité demeure bonne, propulsée par ces douces saveurs de baril, de raisin et de figue. Intense mais très plaisante!

Refrigerated 12.7 green bottle from trapped 2015, poured into a tulip. Clear light red with very small beige head. Aroma is rich grape, medium body, low carbonation, and little lacing. Taste is grape and tart.
375ml bottle of 2015 release. Pours a reddy brown color with a good amount of effervescence. Mild acidity and some funk. Slight stomach acid flavor.

Sample, 1-ounce, during the Great American Beer Festival, savoured on September 25 2015; eye: coppery, clear, no effervescence, ring of beige head, no lacing; nose: acidity, musk, wild yeasts, tannin, red wine, fig; mouth: acidity, musk, wild yeasts, tannin, red wine, fig, slight sourness, finale in red wine with presence of tannin, medium-full body, good carbonation, lightly sweet, vinous texture; overall: fine

FRANÇAIS

Échantillon, 1 once, en fût, durant le Great American Beer Festival, savourée le 25 septembre 2015; il : cuivrée, limpide, pas deffervescence, anneau de mousse beige, pas de dentelle; nez : acidité, musc, levures sauvages, tanin, vin rouge, figue; bouche : acidité, musc, levures sauvages, tanin, vin rouge, figue, très légère aigreur, finale en vin rouge avec présence de tanin, corps moyen-corsé, bonne carbonatation, légèrement sucrée, texture vineuse; en résumé : bien

Beau nez et bouche en profondeur sur des fruits rouges, touche balsamique, rondeur dalcool, malts en support, caramel, notes boisées vibrantes, brettanomyces. Corps plus ou moins lourd, huileuse texture. Sèche, je dirais même très sèche en finale. Pas agressive pour mes papilles, vivement une autre dégustation de ce délicieux truc roux.

2015 batch. From a 375ml bottle into an oversized wine glass. Paid $15 for this sucker. Pours a ruby-red/brown. No head and no lacing. Very much wine like aroma with some lime and red wine vinegar tossed in. Mouthfeel is sweet but dry and moderate... slightly astringent. Lots of tiny bubbles and carbonation. Taste is light red wine with a TON of berry flavor. Sourness is subdued but certainly present. For a sour beer, this is sooooooo smooth and well put together. Wow! its slightly sweet, but not too much; same for sourness; same for carbonation. Tons of berry flavor. Really, really loved this one. For $15 a bottle its not at all cheap, but it is very worth it for a special occasion.
Ruddy pour. Tart vinous aroma. Flavor is similar with some barnyardy (Brett) notes. Quite nice.

Pours mahogany into a tulip. White head with little retention recedes to nothing. Dark pit fruit, funk and oak aromas. Medium bodied with pit fruit and grapes upfront turning to marshmallow brett and band-aid in the lasting finish.

2015 Batch: Oaky lactic sour aroma with almost a grape musk in there. Taste is mostly lactic sour with a bit of an earthy funk finish. Almost a funky grape finish. Almost a slight boozy oakyness to it. Not overly sour, maybe 4 of 10 sour. Complex and has a descent amount of body. Woody and some dark fruit in there with the grape musk. Solid sour for sure, but for the price it is a step below cascade sours or bruery sours, and even a bit more expensive than those for similar volume.

Thnx Rob ! Pours unclear amber , no real head ( looks like wort) Smell is sour, oaky, fruity. Taste is dry sour, lactic acid. Mild fruity. Nice, but not really as complex as expected. Still very nice though

Draft @ BCTC, Ommegang Brewery. August, 8, 2015. Dirty red, muddy brown color. Aroma is a vinegar bomb! Maybe I can get around this aroma and try to be subjective here 
Flavor is acetone, funky red grapes, funky oak with a sharp vinegar that turns into cherries and other random berries. Steady tartness. For a style I completely hate this turned out more drinkable then I was guessing but I sure the hell wouldnt stand in line for it.

Bottle shared thanks to Deanso. Pours cloudy brown with a ring tan head. Aroma of tart red and dark fruits, light funk, vinous notes, caramel and oak. Flavour is light moderate sweet and over moderate sour. Medium bodied with soft carbonation.
Bottle shared. Pours cloudy brown-ish. Aroma is fruity, grapes, red fruits, tart, wood and zest. Taste is moderate sour and light sweet. Medium bodied. Really nice.

Bottle shared at THT May 2015. Courtesy of me, traded with a good friend in New York.
No head. very hazy amber pour. Quite tart.
Thanks to jrob21 for holding onto this and sharing it. Lots of dark red berries, vinous, oak, sour, acidic, medium complexity. Nice stuff.
Batch 4. Beautiful color. Reddish brown. Thick syrupy aroma. Flavor is a little more tart. Full bodied and intense. Finish is a little fruity and tart. Could have a little more depth but really nice

Bottle: Batch 4. Murky, red-tinted & chestnut brown body with a beige foam that quickly settles to a small ring. Aroma of cherry skin, sharp tannin, vinous & slightly boozy wood, moderately musty funk, red grape, some cobweb. Flavor has a nice vinous tartness with lots of grape & vinousness as it warms like a red wine. Faint notes of tobacco, vinegar, under-ripe tart cherry, & a hint of wood. Finishes with a touch of booze. Mild acidity on the way down. Really nice stuff.

Poured a pale rust red color with aromas of cranberry, oak, light raspberries and some sour jam qualities. Flavors match the aromas with some nice sour and tartness solid overall could drink a lot if this.

Pours a rusty crimson color with a finger plus of eggshell foam. Nose is bright, vinous and sharp in a focused way. Raspberry, cranberry, moss, wet wood. Palate follows with nice tannic structure, very vinous, funky pinot noir acidity and a soft fuzzy carbonation ! Delicious.

beige head collapses quickly. redbrown colour. aroma is lactic acid, glue, solvent, cherries, wood, almonds, vinous. taste is citric acid, vinegar, almonds, cherries, vinous, yoghurt dry mouthfeel. medium body and carbonation. an awesome balance, comes real close to rodenbach grand cru and vintage. one of the best sours ive had from the usa .. by far!! bottle 35.5cl / batch #4
Bottle - Pours thin amber. The nose is viscous, sour, grapes and wine. Taste is sour upfront with hints of grapes, lemon zest, tart and light vinegar notes.

Lovely rose-hued, hazed pour with a clinging ring of pink-tinted white. Gravel, balsamic vinegar, sherry and cheese rind in the nose; funky and angular, with expansive depth. Dry chocolate introduces another level; sweat sock like mold and cheese notes detract. The flavor often sings with gorgeously layered fruit; blood orange, cranberry, and red grape are enveloped in elegant spicing and quiet density. The palate, warm and gently acidic, offers tenacity knowingly restrained; acid level is firm at the finish, with a kinder softness about it. Pleasant, detailed and calmer sour overall.

Got this through ufck BIF. Pours deep ruby red with a small wisp of beige. Aroma is tart cherry and oak. Taste is very tarte, some wet blanket, cherry and grape. More puckerish than Rodenbach. Quite nice sipper.

Bottle. Pours an amber-y raspberry color. Aroma is lemon, orange, light red wine, booze, honey, balsamic. Taste is sour raspberry and wine grapes, Sweet Tarts, lingering tartness and syrupy sweetness. Nice balance of sweet and tart. Very good.
shared bottle. poured a dark red amber colour with some white bubbles on top. red wine, oak, grapes, plums, cherries, vinegar, balsamic, slight acid brett,
Dark brownish red with a small white ring around the glass. Aroma of red grapes and funky butt-hole cheddar. Mouth puckering sour cherry and grape mist.
bottleshare thanks to DexterCat. Tart. Sour. Pretty good. Lots of makt. My rates suck. Why are you reading this. Go home. Stop judging me.
Poured into crystal wine glass. Reddish color, fairly hazy. Tart sour dark fruity aroma. Tart sour sweet tart, dark fruits, more sour. Yummy.
Draft - Vintage 2010 - Cherry and oak notes with a bit balsamic. Clear caramel with no head. Tart, caramel and really nice.
Bottle poured into wine glass. Reddish brown with low head. Aroma is tart grape and oak. Taste is big tart and vinous, great fruity finish

Bottle via trade. Batch 4. Pours a murky dark red, almost purple with little to no head. Aromas of creamy yogurt, oak, sour dark fruit. Taste is bitter and off dry. Flavor comes off as a little artificial... like flavoring was added. Never a good thing. Very oak moss, a touch too sweet, low carb. Meh.

UPDATED: APR 4, 2014 First beer of EBF 2014! Im not going to even go in to an exensive, structured rating. This was just fucking awsome. Perfect malt balance, sourness was all malo-lactic with a good brett kick and very light on the grapes. Red wine barrel brightens things and add some complexity but leave the yeast and bacteria to do its thing.More than anything, I just want to highlight how ridiculous these fests can get. There was literally never a wait to get a beer from Captain Lawrence, at any point in the fest, whereas most of the "Popular Brewers" had 10-15 minute waits. Not trying to be Captain Cynical here, but for gods sake, make up your own mind on beers and try the "little guys". Strange, though, that Capt. Lawrence is just a little guy. Theyve put out so many world class beers, yet they get very little notoriety these days. Quietly brewing some of the best sours around. This beer was pretty close to perfect. Mouthfeel, balance, complexity, attenuation. Amazing.

Échantillonné du Extreme beer fest 2014: Une bombe acétique et vineuse très sèche avec une multitudes de petits fruits. La soupe est également assez funky, bretté et grasse par moment, vraiment solide.

Bottle from trade. Pours deep red purple with a a small beige head. Smells delicious, tart cherry pie, raspberry, yogurt funk. Flavor follows nose, lots of tart cherry, raspberry, yogurt funkiness. Finishes dry, black raspberry.

On tap at EBF my first beer in wine cask with hint of grapes

Really nice tart sour with grapes, a tart cherry and a bit of funk/oak/wine in there too. Nice ruby color and great tart palate with a bunch if wine flavor. Real solid overall

From a bottle at the EBF Saturday
Nice fruity tart and funk, really enjoyed this beer.
375 ml. bottle. Thanks Tom! Pours reddish brown (more red than brown) with a small off-white head. Aroma of tart fruit and funk. Taste is tart cherries, lemon, citrus, funk, and wood. Very nice Sour.
Pours reddish brown with a nice foamy tan head. strong aromas of funk, yeast, and grapes. Taste is a fruity champagne with a dry finish. The malt comes through on the initial taste. Nice sour.

375mL bottle, sent from Glouglouburp (thanks a lot, Dany), pours an opaque still dark mahogany with almost no head. Aroma is very complex, with loads of wild yeast, dry dark fruits, some vinous notes, and oak. Flavour is remarkably elegant and complex, with lots of oaky wood, dry red wine, light wild yeasts, and subtle very dry dark fruit. Lightly funky, vinous and very dry on the finish. A sour brown of wonderful complexity.
Awesome brew, thank you GT2! Really nice sour ale, loved it, aged in wine barrels, yum

From Chris. Thanks! Batch 4.

A: Quick foaming head that dies like it was overpoured cola. Cola colored red with bubbles.

N: Acetic cherry, pepper, oak, some raspberry. Leather and overripe grapes.

T: Sour with a round wood sensation. Very acidic and lacking in complexity. Some oxide? Feels like its over-aged.

M: Heavy carbonation with a chalky lighter body.

O: This edition is not up to par. Seems like previous batches have been more complex.

Batch 4 - thanks Tooch4321! Pours hazy ruby, small off-white head and decent lacing. Very beautiful in the glass. Aroma is tart lemon, oaky, cherry, vinous, funk, basement. Flavor is initially sweet and fruity with light tartness and a bit of oaky astringency. Dries out on the finish leaving oaky and vinous notes behind. Medium body, very low carbonation. Nice nice beer.

Bottle shared by b3shine. Poured a hazy reddish brown color with an average frothy off-white head with good lacing. Moderate to heavy tannic fruit and sour yeast aroma. Medium to full body and a smooth texture and soft carbonation. Medium to heavy sour & grape flavor with a medium to heavy grape & sour finish of moderate to long duration. This is a complex beer.

12.7oz bottle, shared by b3shine. Batch 4. Hazy brown / red color. Minimal off-white head. No lace sticks. Awesome fruity sour cherry aroma in the nose. Toasty wood notes, light spice. Very nice sour fruity cherry nose. Raspberry. Medium-plus body. Smooth, lighter carbonation. Lightly sticky finish. Reasonably easy drinking for a sour. Good bigger sour taste, light sweet, light spicy. Very nice, tasty, complex sour. Good vinous notes.

A: Amber/Light Orangish Hue, Passes Some Light, White Head Ring, Some Lacing

S: Sour Mash, Tart Cherries, Black Pepper

T: Sour Mash, Tart Cherries, Black Pepper

M: Decent Carbonation, Medium Bodied, Sour, Mild Bitterness

Overall, a really sold and clean flaunder ale
GABF 2013. Dark brown. Awesome nose of wet oak and fruit. Real red wine character. Quite tart but balanced sweetness. Really good-one of my favorites of the night.

Draft at GABF. Pour is murky brown pour and a small white head - good lacing. Huge acidic and sour fruity, tannin peach skin, woody, almost roasty, and light spice in the aroma. Taste is huge acid, red wine vinegar, woody, some raspberry, cherries, and tangy dark fruits. Slick mouthfeel with soft carbonation. Nice sour, but would score a little higher if it wasnt so acidic.

375 ml bottle to snifter (shared by me with the group; thanks tgncc). Looks good; a cloudy brown with thin off-white lacing. Smells tart and funky with a grape presence. Tastes like it smells, only more robust. Nice and lively on the palate. Good stuff!
Bottle at WTWBA. Hazy red pour. White soapy head. Very sour. Puckering. Cherry and mild wood. Nice.

375ml bottle in a tulip. Pours cloudy red/brown with a small head. Aroma of grapes, some oak and light vanilla, a nice sourness and funky note, a good amount of caramel and slightly darker malts. Flavor a nice blend of everything. Average texture. A good sour.

Deep red, no head.

Smell is typical oud bruin, bit lactic but not overpowering.

Taste smooth cherry vanilla, light tart.

medium body

Good

On tap at The Old toad New Brew - New York night. Wow, this one was complex. Pours murky reddish brown color with tan head. Musty aroma with grapes, cherries, oak and brett. Very sour cherry, grape tannins and vinous flavors with some oak and tartness. Medium body with moderate carbonation. Hard for me to get used to these Sours.

Bottle shared at a sour tasting at the Beer & Beyond shop. Pours brown hazy with a small head, aroma of brett, tiers, red wine and plums, flavor is sourish with wood, vinegar, dried fruits, medium bodied, tasty

Campground Throwdown 2, 33cl, thanks yobdoog. Muddy brown body with no head. Aroma is moderately sweet, sour, lemon, vinous, wood. Taste is moderately sweet, sour, vinous, some wood, cherry. Medium body, some acidity, light stickiness.

Batch #3.
Aroma is a balanced blend of acidity and grapes. Slight acetic character. Moderate fruit notes from the grapes and some medium low oak notes. Medium light funk and moderate tart cherries also present. 
Pours an auburn brown with ruby highlights. Somewhat murky. Thin slightly off white head that disappears almost immediately. 
Flavor hits with a bit of sweetness but then a sharp acidity. Slightly sweet grape jam notes upfront, then the grape notes turn fairly tart. Some Brett funk but more on the fruity side than barnyard with some cherries. Light oak notes and tannins. Slight acetic character to the acid but mostly lactic. Some citrus fruit and grapefruit notes as the beer warms. 
Mouthfeel is medium bodied with medium carbonation. Low acidic astringency and low alcohol warmth. 
Overall a fairly nice beer but quite the acid bomb. I would prefer a little less acid and tannins and a bit more barnyard funk. Nice balance of grapes and cherry notes from the Brett.
UPDATED: AUG 30, 2013 at warrens funky 9. definitely some higher alcohols. a dark aged fruit aroma. murky red tinted color. its got a nice aged fruit flavor and reasonable sourness.

Pours a still deep purple redish hue. Complex aroma resembles raspberry jam, oak, and vinegar. High acidity meets a low carbonation leading to a interesting high acid wine like body. Flavors changes with time, this is refreshingly interesting oaky and delicious sour but not something Id want to drink a lot of.

Bottle sample at a sour tasting at the Beer & Beyond shop. Thanks DSG. Hazy brown with cream coloured wave. Wood, sour grapes, perfume aroma, greenish sourness in the mouth, astringent. Full bodied yet thin textured. Tough one.

UPDATED: DEC 21, 2013 Batch 4, 375ML bottle enjoyed at home at fridge temp. Ive rated this already at Ommegangs Belgian event...oops. Posting new notes below.

A -  Color is very much a mix of cherry and grapes. Murky blood red against the light. Fizzy carbonation fades fast. 

S - Figs, prune juice and lactic acid on the nose. Looking at my notes, the nose is not as good as I remember. Very bath-water, mustiness.

T -  Overwhelmingly sour. The grapes add a tartness that just makes the beer way more sour. Vinegar still present with brett funk at the finish. Nice cherry and grape

M - Thin and oily

O - Dang. Wish I hadnt opened this. Probably would have sent away to someone who hasnt had it before. Still nice but certainly way too sour for me and so one dimensional.
Bottle Bath #4..Pour is brownish with a thin white tan head..Nose is cherry, funk, wet wood, fruits, sweetness, tartness..Taste is tartness, dry oak,spice, cherry, fruits, brown sugar, acidic..
375ml bottle pours a cloudy amber with a very minimal head. Grape and vinegar aroma. Tart fruit a bit of a wood taste.

Bottle thanks to a trade. Pours a clear ruby red with a thin white head that starts at the edges and dissipates completely. Aroma has a good amount of sour red fruits supported by a dry red wine note and a hint of oak. Flavor has sour red fruit that have a decent amount of acidity and the finish has dry red wine.

Bottle shared by Derek. Pours hazy orange chestnut with a thin white head thAt dissipated. Nose is tart red grapes over woody earthy oak. Taste has a complexity that really points to its time in the barrel.
Bottle at my buddys ba tasting. Loads of tart cherry with a little vanilla and wood. My oh my is this tasty. Ill have to be on the lookout for more of this.

Bottle purchased at the brewery. Batch 4. Pours muddy dark brown with barely noticeable carbonation. Aroma immediately reminds me of Belgian lambic wild yeast. Flavor follows on that impression. This tastes and feels very much like a good gueuze except for the residual sweetness, which actually gives the brew a nice balance. Very drinkable and very good.

Bottle shared at a sour tasting at the Beer & Beyond shop. Batch #4. Murky brown. Aroma of cherries, wood, vinous notes, malt and a bit of caramel and a barnyard notes. Sour flavor with vinegar, cherries, a bit of grapes and some malt, a bit caramelly, with a bit of sweetness. Medium-bodied.
Aroma is sweaty bandaid funk, peaches, sour red apple, and oak. Pours red with little film. Taste is nice and tart with apricot, vinegar, tart cherry, and Oak. Good vinegar zing. Great sour.

Pours an opaque purple/brown color with a medium tan/pinkish head.  Aroma has mild grape sweetness and nice vinous and oak notes...mild tartness.  Flavor has very brief sweet grape that is quickly consumed by lots of oak and sour and vinous grape...some acidity.  Mouthfeel is light and silky with a sour/vinous finish that fades to oak.
Bottle. Hazy red beer with a small pink head. Sourish, woody. vanilla, fruity, yeasty, rubber and oaky aroma. Sourish, raspberries, leather, raisins, vanilla. oak, hay flavour.

UPDATED: JUN 8, 2013 Batch 4 thanks to Tom, thanks man! Pours a slightly murky brown/red. Aroma is really fruity and reminescent of La Roja (could it be the benchmark for american sours?). There is also a nice lacto sharpness to it. Taste is sweet but not too much. Flavors are once again fruity with grapes dominating but there are other notes in there too: strawberry and cherries mostly. There is also a fun vinegar in there although a bit too soft for my liking I think. A really good american sour ale!

Batch #4 - Murky brown pour with a head that fades real quick.  Nose of grapes, fruit, brett, and light vinegar.  Taste follows the know with tons of vinous qualities.  Also picking up some barrel character.  Good stuff but probably a little young.

Pours a dark red with little pink head that falls quickly and no lacing. Aroma of tart, caramel, oak. Taste is tart, fruity, some sweetness, lit acetic notes. Low body and low carb. Very good.

Bottle. Pours murky red with no head. Funky cherry aroma. Taste is slight sweet and funky fruit.

Pours dark brownish red with no head. Aroma of lacto, Brett, red wine and grapes. Taste follows, sour grapes, lacto and Brett lots of redwine and oak. Really amazing sour.

Deep red color with minimal head. Aroma has fruity and tart notes. Taste isnt as tart as I was expecting but that is not a bad thing. This has a fantastic balance of fruit flavor and tartness. Very enjoyable.
Bottle shared by my good friend Ed, thanks man. What a way to cap off an awesome tasting. Tons of tart flavors with a nice balance between the sour and fruit. I hope he has more!

Bottle at captain Lawrence beer dinner at blue monk. Dark brown ruby red pour with a thin off white head. smells cherry tart with lots of oak and quite boozey. Taste is very tart. Cherries and cherries and cherries. Bitter finish. Some red wine elements to it, very pleasant.

Thanks a lot to OldSock for the thoughtful share. This is a beer I have wanted to try for a few years, and somehow the stars never aligned until tonight. 

The beer is hazy chestnut brown with a thin tan head. Audible hissing as the head rapidly fades. The aroma is grand, offering plenty of sourness and funk, with prominent yeast, fruits, caramels, bread. Sharp and biting feel, but not unpleasant. Certainly acetic though. A nice beer to sip and savor with a friend or two. Double digit alcohol is disguised quite well. A really solid beer, though not for everyone.
UPDATED: JUN 19, 2013 Batch 4. Fart smell. I think it could have used more grape cripsness and less of the iwine characteristic. Nice sourness, pleasant ale.

Bottle from taproom. Pours dark grape brown with a thin khaki head that leaves a bit of lacing. A bit of grape must on the nose. lots of red wine notes on the tongue. Nice sour notes on the finish. Solid though I wonder if this will become bigger as it ages.
Bottle of batch #4 - pours a foggy garnet with a white head. Aroma is musty, and has a sourness to it. The taste is sour with a wateriness that finishes dryly. Overall, its interesting.

Trade from jrgratz. Batch #4 and my first Captain Lawrence. Thanks!!! Pours a cloudy red with a big pink head that dissapates quickly. Smell is very sour cherry and vinegar. Beautiful sour cherry flavor with dry oak and a hint of sour grape. Much creamier mouthfeel than I have had from a sour. Prickly carbonation and a long lasting sour on the palate. No ABV content but there seems to be a bit of warmth on this.

Batch 3 - pours cloudy orangish brown with a tan ring. Smell is sour cherry, grape skins, quite sour. Taste is similar to smell with sharp sourness. Nice carbonation and light in body. Overall, still my favorite Captain Lawrence sour.

batch 4, opened after day one of release

poured a dark grape juice.  aroma of brett and grapes. poured with zero carb, hopefully over time this stuff comes to life.  Flavor was sour grapes, and simple delicious.

Bottle 375ml.
Pours hazy ligth chestnut with particules. Low beige head. Aroma is of vinegar, fruits, sweetness. Taste is of vinegar, fruits, acidity, paint thinner, sweetness. Way too much vinegar. Palate: Ligth body. Some sugar in there (sticky). Overall: Too much vinegar, cloying. Nice fruits. A decent sour anyways, but I would not seek this again.

Bottle (375 ml). Thanks to readbaron! Murky amber with almost no head and no lacing. Aroma is of red fruits (cherries, red fruits), phenols, oak, vinegar and slight winey notes. Taste is of red fruit, oak, vinegar/acetic notes and a slight wine presence. Mouth puckering. Dry. Acetic. Low carbonation. Not perfectly balanced, but a really good Sour Ale.

batch 2 bottle shared by fred82 - many thanks! pours unclear light reddish with a small off-white cap, decent retention. dusty and dry bretts with loads of red fruitiness - cherries and red grapes along with their phenols and red grape skins astringency. subtle oakiness. few acetic and lactic notes - light to medium acidity and light lactose sweetness - good balance. average to soft carbonation, light to medium body - oily without it being sticky, nice lightly acidic and tingling spicy, grassy-citrusy finish. reminiscence of caractère rouge. very good brew!

Batch 1- Hazy red-copper hue with moderate head.  Aromas are filled with a chalky cherry funk, very light on the acidic notes, underlying cocoa powder.  The nose does not make my eyes water like the batch 3 has in the past.  Mouthfeel is very light, the fruit is still very bright upfront, with the cherry still intact.  Mid palate acidity is soft, but the finish is a cascading sour funk that starts as if it were going to be nothing at all, then rips hard into a lingering tart backend.  Very long finish.  The overall on this one is 19/20, I find that after 4 years of cellering that this is as good as it will get, very balanced, the abv is well hidden, the acidity levels have decreased dramatically from that of the batch 3 fresh.  I found that the only minor flaw from keeping this perfect was the slight lack of cherry in the front which show signs of fading somewhat soon.  With 3 more left, I would reccommend the next batch 1 to be tasted in July 2013 at another 6 months.

Bottle, acquired for ritual sacrifice at THE fruit sour tasting. The pours deep hazy red with a tiny off-white head. The nose is big juicy red grapes, rotting red fruits, toast, lactic funk and sugar. The taste is booze, funky lactic acid, woody wild bugs. Cherry jam sweetness, big funky vinous, mild balsamic and skunk. Hot finish. Overall, definitely a big ragged. Still, this had plenty of character, so I enjoyed it.

Bottle (Batch 3) thanks to Jack at THE fruit sour tasting. It pours cloudy deep red with a tiny off-white head. The nose is wood, toasted coconut, vanilla, sweet-sour aspect, red grape and slight jamminess. The taste is red grape, red grapefruit, plum, big on the acidity, light jam, wood, vinegar and raspberry yoghurt with a somewhat acidic finish. Medium body, fine prickly carbonation and slightly sticky mouth-feel. As with the Cuvee de Castleton this is not particularly complex but is still rather drinkable.
Sampled at UCTS testing. Pours dirt brown with a small dirty head. Smells moldy strawbarries and sour. Tastes very sour, bitter, moldy red barries with a similar finish.

375 ml bottle courtesy of rlgk. Pours slightly dirt brown red with a small fizzy pinkish offwhite head that quickly dissipates without leaving any trace on the glass. Smell is sour and fruity with crackers, red wine vinegar, dark grapes, woody tannins, dark plums, overripe lemons, bilberries and lemon juice. Taste is sour and tart with crackers, dark grapes, red wine vinegar, woody tannins, lemon juice, bilberries, raspberries, red currants, unripe gooseberries, leather and hay. Mouthfeel is dry, fruity tart and medium bodied. Finish is sour and tart with lemon juice, dark grapes, woody tannins, bilberries, red currants, unripe gooseberries and red wine vinegar.

(Bottle) Pours orange brown with a fizzy head. The aroma holds lacto, blue grapes, apples, red berries, touch of wood, whisper of barnyard and grainy, bready malt. The flavor is fairly dry and heavily acidic with notes of aggressive citrus, lacto, light funk, tart red berries, blue grapes, medicine, light wood and bready malt. The mouthfeel is tart and light astringent with light carbonation. Uber citric finish. Near medium bodied.

Bottle at USA comes to Skövde. Hazy amber/orange beer with a small offwhite head. Woody fruity aroma, yeasty, apples, grapes, oak, vanilla notes, rubber, leather, grapefruit notes. Woody sour flavor, raspberries, strawberries, leather, grapefruit, oak, vanilla notes, hay, raisins, tart, some grapes.

Sampled at USSkovde
Murky amber. Very brief head. 
Sour/acidic aroma and flavour; vinegar. Way to acidic. 
Red berries.

Batch 3 served in a Portsmouth tulip. Not sure who shared, but thanks!

A: Pours a dark grape-like color with a dirty white head forming on the pour. It recedes to a thin ring and leaves some splotchy lace.

S: Tart green apple and lime rind with a lemony pith. There is some sweet fruit, maybe grape or some dark berry. Slight whiff of alcohol.

T: The taste follows the nose with some tart fruit skins, dark sweet fruits and mild acetone on the finish.

M: Medium to light bodied. For how big this beer is it drinks quite nicely. Medium carbonation.

O: Ive never had an oud bruin that was this big and robust, but it drank like it was much lighter. Very solid and glad I was able to get to try this.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 05-19-2012

375ml bottle, batch 3, from a trade but once again cannot remember from whom.  Clear light mahogany with a biege head that fades to just a faint rim.  Interesting combination of tannins and sour cherries, bit of funk, dry, alcohol, acidic.Low carbonation, moderate body, sour and tart, cherries, very very dry.

Pours a very low carb syrupy looking brown color with no head.  Aroma is dark fruits, grapes, oak, musty funk, and lemon.  Taste is nicely funky with light sweetness and a heavy tartness that is very nice.  This beer was fantastic.
Wow this is incredible. Very Russian riveresque. Extremely tart flavor profile. Simply amazing

UPDATED: JAN 5, 2013 2nd June 2010Cloudy brown beer, no head. Dry palate. Pretty sour, a bit too much with sourness! Sharp lemon that is only partially offset by the wood. Winey sourness at the end. Just too much lemon. 2.4.23rd November 2012THE Fruit Sour tasting. Thanks Jack. Vinegary sweet and sour with a little worcester sauce. Enjoyed this a lot more second time around.

Batch 3 (I think) shared by Thorpe429, thanks!

Beer is brown and hazy with a thin head, no lacing, moderate to low carbonation.

Beer is woody and acetic with strong lactic notes in the nose. Smells exactly like what I thought it would.

Making an Oud Bruin is a difficult beer. It is hard to pull off in general and this is a great example of one. I really like this beer. It is thin and bright, acetic and tannic. Very nice finish, mildly dry. Id have it again, looking forward to tasting the other vintages and releases.

Serving type: bottle

Bottle, 37,5 cl, big thx to Kan. Pours cloudy ruby mahogany with a small off white shortlived head. Aroma is intense vinous, sweet, caramel, toffee, malty, barrel, fruity and sour vinegar. Flavor is sweet sour in front with acetonic fruity touch, a bit shocking to my mouth on the first sip, what an intensity. Second sip reveals fruits, barrel harshness, more pleasant sourness, grapes and some sweetness. Towards the end a nice tingling pungent peppery feeling over my tounge together with the remaining sour and fruity flavors and some bitterness creeping out while the other flavors dissapear. Finishes with pleasant fruity and sour, mouth watering aftertaste.

Courtesy of Tooch4321 via trade 
Bottle: The aroma consists of huge sour grapes, lemon, and grape bubblegum. Its pours a muddy orangish-brown with a minimal off-white head. The flavor starts with a a quick does of a quick dose of lemon. Theres a fruitiness in the background. The finish has sour grapes, lemon, a hint of acetone, and and a touch of oak. Its medium bodied with mild carbonation.

Sample courtesy of Mike at Capones. Huge thanks for letting me try the other rare sour ale from the Captain. Pours a red tinted brown color. Murky in appearence. Head was very small, lacing was as well but was lasting. Incredible sour aromas punch you in the face when swirled around. Notes of sour cherry, ripe red grapes, oaky butter, chocolate bar, red wine, and raisin. Taste is juicy grapes with heavy brett, belgian spices, soft wood from the barreling, and a cinnamon apple wash at the finish. Amazing beer that reminds me somewhat of Amazing Grace from Lost Abbey. Excellent wild ale. Cheers

From notes.  First reviewed 9/23/2011.  Batch 2. Poured from a 375 mL bottle into a tulip.

Rosso E Marrone pours a raspberry color with caramel brown edges. A tiny off-white head lingers for a bit but eventually fades.

The aroma is of slowly decaying raspberry and grape. Lots of barnyard funk. Tart lactic cherries as well. This is very interesting and really excites my olfactory system.

The flavor is quite tart, with decomposing red grape and raspberry flavors. Lots of raunchy funk toward the end of the sip. Nice full cherry tannins and oak add some depth to the sour flavor.

This has a light to medium carbonation and a medium body. I am surprised that it is not fuller, given the 10% ABV. The tartness creates some salivation and it fairly acidic.

Overall, this is simply delicious.

Batch 2. 
Ive been staring at this beer in my fridge waiting 2 weeks for a night where my allergies werent making me want to die.

A - reddish brown with finger of off white head, recedes to a few small bubbles around the rim.

S - I could smell the grapes the second I opened the bottle. Also brett, vinegar, and oak.

T - Initial acetic sourness with a nice grape character. A decent amount of malts makes this a little sweeter than Id like. 

M/D - very tannic and dry when it was straight from the fridge. Body really develops once its warmed, carbonation is barely noticeable.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 10-07-2010

Bottle to snifter batch 2. Pours blood orange and cloudy with little to no head. Aroma is funky cheese and fruit with wet leather and sour. Taste is all of the above with the sourness strong and acidic (awesome). Palate is medium and dry and acidic. Really nice brew that I will try to get again!

UPDATED: NOV 19, 2012 Batch 3. Murky brown pour; hazy, golden hues. Strong oak barrel presence in the nose. Tart fruit, grapes, yeast, and cherries too. Interesting and complex taste: opens fruity and sour, strong barrel flavors in the middle, really nice blend. Mouth-puckering sourness. This is an intensely flavored sour, and it really grew on me as I sipped. Between this and CDC, Iâve become a full convert to the glory of Capt Lawrence. Not missing another release, thatâs for sure.

Bottle.  Aroma has notes of barnyard funk, horseblanket, urine, bretty funk, cereal malts, sweat and wonderful citrus sourness.  Medium rusty brown hazy hue with a medium off-white head that mostly diminished and left no lace.  Flavor is medium sweet and bitter and very sour.  Palate is medium bodied and vinegary.  Overall a wonderfall sour brew that rivals the best Europe has to offer.  Tar, sour and citrus with a very well developed funkiness.  Wonderful in every regard and a great example of the style.

Side by side tasting of batch 2 and 3 thanks to Doodler and bauermj. Thanks guys! 

Batch 2: It pours reddish amber/copper with a very small head that disappears. The aroma is intense of oak, berries, vinous grapes and lemony lactic acid. Very light hints of vinegar. The flavor is dry and very acidic with heavy accents of oak, lemon, tart grapes and toasty brett in the finish. Wow, this was really acidic. Throat burningly so, but not much acetic which is good. Overall, I give it a 4.0. I just love sours...

Batch 3:  Same pour as batch two with a slightly longer lasting head, yet it disappears within a minute as well. The aroma is also the same with surprisingly more depth to the toasty leathery funk. Interesting since this is a fresher batch. The vinous berry and grape aroma is more subdued taking a backseat to a stronger sharp lemony acid. Nice. The flavor is vinous and definitely less acidic than batch 2. More grapes and funkier in the finish with leather and horseblanket. Overall, less acid and more funk make this more drinkable than batch 2. I give it a 4.2

It was weird how the aroma was more acidic in batch 3, yet the flavor was more mellow. I split the difference between the two to give this an overall 4.1. Very well done.

375 ml bottle.  Batch 2.  Thanks for sharing Phyllis.  Pours a cloudy brownish amber with no head.  The aroma is big grape, some light brett, some caramel sweetness, and some lactic acid.  The taste is sweet and quite sour.  Big grape, some lactic and acetic acid, and a light brett funkiness.  The finish is moderately dry with a bit of earthiness.  Medium body.  Low carbonation.  It definitely could have used some more carbonation.  Not bad, but nothing special.

UPDATED: DEC 12, 2011 batch 3 bottle.  initial aroma is red wine barrel, chocolate covered raspberries, and a pleasant brown sugar apple crisp character.     taste is bright sour red grapes, neat, unique, almost juice like purple grape character.  some pleasant smooth creamy leather.   touch of balsamic and oak.  moderate-heavy sourness. dry.     overall, a quite drinkable, complex tasty redwine, juicy cider, purple grape sour beer.

Batch 3 bottle shared by my man Rasmusott. The color is lovely on this one - blood orange red, but only the slightest amount of head - quickly dissipating. Aroma is very brett forward, musty, a very clear vinegary component like balsamico, cherries, lacto, lots of oak, a dried grape component like an Amarone wine, musry red wine barrel, slight hint of raisins. Lots of vanilla and a hint of acetone. The taste is nicely sour, lactic acid, cherries, funky brett, wine barrel, some stinging sourness, mouth-drying brett, tart white grapes, lime bitterness. Some elements remind me of Duchesse de Bourgogne, but this is more funky and acidic. Very nice.

UPDATED: AUG 1, 2014 Trade with Arminjewell. Aroma is huge with brett, cherry, oud brunish, red and green apples, vinegar, balsamic, sweet oak, black grapes, a sweeter winey quality to it, alot of wild funkyness to it and weak vanilla. So nice balance in the aroma. Taste is sweet and sour with cherries, brett, lacto acid, wild funkyness, balsamic, sweet oak, tart, barnyard, some sweeter ripe fruits and some black grapes here aswel.

UPDATED: SEP 23, 2014 38cl, Batch 1, no mention of ABV, exclusive American brew, with red grapes, from De Hopduvel Gent, complex sour brew, woody/fruity and slightly vinous, balanced, cloudy, nearly no head, good brew, yet very expensive!

Bottle batch 2 traded by MaxxDaddy, thanks man! Shared with Chris, Mikkel and Rune. 
Pours hazy orange with a white head.
Aroma is sour and earthy, with notes of grapes, and apples. 
Tastes is sour sweet with notes of apples, grape, grapes and oak.

Bottle at GABF. I was really excited for this one, but alas. Pours a brownish red with some fizzy head that dissipates. There are notes of booze and plastic. Strong phenolic properties that really detract from the beer. Soft and tart with some funk. Just not right. Perhaps it was just this  bottle, but not good.

Batch 1, 2, and 3 side-by-side tasting with bsuedekum and STLWill- thanks for the contributions, Will and Blake! Pours a red-tinted amber with a tiny beige ring for a head; batch 2 is virtually clear, with batch 3 the murkiest. The aroma has a lot of vanilla, caramel, coconut, and oak in batch 1 to go with grapes; 2 is almost all brett and red grapes; 3 is woody and earthy, with dirt and unripened fruit along with oak and some bretty funk. Batch 1 shows more brett and red grape juiciness and tartness, with caramel and oak taking a backseat; 2 has a ton of berries and grapes- red wine and oak; 3 is a lot of red wine and earth, with bretty funk, oak, and caramel. All three are tart and fruity with low carbonation and a light-medium mouthfeel that finishes tart. Batch 1: 9/4/8/5/17, Batch 2: 8/4/8/4/16, Batch 3: 7/4/8/4/15. Im letting the nose on 1 drag it up a little bit because its so damn nice.

sample at GABF on 9/20/11.  deep orange / red pour with a small white head.  tart nose with funk, barnyard and wine qualities.  medium body - vinous - lactic acid - raspberry notes.  dry sour finish with more fruit.  excellent!
Sampled at GABF 2011.  Hazy orange pour.  Incredible sour aroma of lemons, apples, and oak.  Nice tart flavor with lemon and sour grape notably.  In perfect balance.  An incredible sour ale.
Gabf. Hazy, light burnt orange appearance with an off white head. Funky, light raspberry, moderately tart aroma. Very nice, funky, tart raspberry, fruity flavor.
Very hazy orange to red colour. Smells fruity, bit sour, musty and cellar. Tastes fruity, sour and earthlike. Balanced. Good palate.

Batch 3 shared by Jason.  The beer pours to reddish amber body with a thin whitish head.  The aroma is intensely sour fruits with some Sweet Tarts.  As odd as that sounds, it was incredibly complex and smelled great.  The flavor is sour acidic rhubarb and vinous like.  Grapes and chocolate and cherries.  Lots of complex fruits and acids.  The palate is acidic and tart.  Pretty low pH with lots of carbonation.  Left the mouth watering.

Bottled, Batch 3.  Poured fairly clear, earthy orange with a fizzy cap of beige head.  The aroma picked up sour cherries, funky Brett, tangy oak, and a hit of ripe cheese.. assertive, but well-balanced.. great bite on the back of the nose. The flavor held serve.. near-metallic barrel, grape skins, and sour cherries throughout.. scaldingly dry, fruity funk extended outward and stuck on the finish.. moderate-plus sourness.. loved it!  Medium-bodied and dry as mentioned on the palate.. somewhat salty too.. flowed very well, and kept me wanting more.

Bottle from a trade with ksurkin. Huge thanks Ken! Batch #3. Pours murky reddish brown color with tan head. Musty aroma with grapes, cherries, oak and brett. Very sour cherry, grape tannins and vinous flavors with some oak and tartness. Medium body with moderate carbonation. Excellent. Thanks again Ken.

Bottle Batch #3. Murky red brown pour with a ring of white foam. Aroma is earthy, lots of cherries, red wine, grape, light acetic notes. Tastes like cranberries, very sour, some residual sugar, quite tannic and winey. Palate is very full bodied, well carbed, alcohol warmth on the finish. A bit intense and not all that well made to my taste.

Much Thanks to Veldrid
Pour is a murky woody red.  Aroma is delightfully complex. Aroma is Sour grapes, deep red wine influence, woody, sweet red grape, this would be great by itself by under all of this is a blanket of tangy brett.  Flavor is massive red wine, woody, horsey brett, lightly puckering, soft tannic dryness.  So Lovely.

Huge thanks to FooFaa for bringing these to the Inaugural "Imminent Liquidation Bottle Share" Event.

Batch 1 & 2 tasted one after the other, starting with batch one. *My numerical ratings are for the batch one*

A - Both pour hazy amber, bordering on light red, with a small one finger tall head leaving light webs of lacing down the glass.

S - The batch one definitely has more sourness than the batch two. Both have hints of tart cherries, oak, dry brett yeast, and dulled red wine. I would say batch one was the clear winner in this category.

T - Batch one has way more sourness to it, while batch two has more brett and horse blanket dryness. Both have some underlining sweetness to go along with plenty of sour grapes, tart cherries, oak, and dry yeast. Finish on both is bone but it doesnt linger for very long. I greatly preferred the batch one but I still enjoyed the batch two. Very good stuff.

M - Both have a medium body and flavor with moderate carbonation. Batch one has quite a bit of pucker in the feel, while batch two has more of a bretty yeast feel to it. I prefer batch one here as well.

D - Very nice stuff. I would say batch one was the clear winner. The batch two seemed to be still developing a bit but I am not sure if it will ever get to batch ones level. Thanks again Dan for the chance to try these side by side.

Batch 3. hazy amber color/ tan head. Dry wood grape skin, pale malt, red vinegar aromas. Light bodied with soft co2. Dry wood, grape tannin sour/tart flavors with a fruity sweet cherry, grape juice, oxidized caramel sweetness to balance--very good

text: Murky dark brown body. Superb aroma, reminiscent of Aardmonnik, earth, spices, sourness, prunes, vinegar. Taste is remarkable, especially through its blending of flavours. Grand, and lengthy, aftertaste.

Bottle: Batch #2 Thanks to Joes for sharing:

text: Almost no head, but a very nice dark copper color. Complex malty, but most fruity aroma, slightly sour, with hints of wine, cherry, raspberry, almond and marzipan. Well balanced taste with an upcoming, soft and fruity sourness. Cherry, almond and caramel softly dominate.
Thanks to Joes for sharing! Copper / light amber color, almost no head. Smells like a geuze; sour! Taste sour but decently balanced. Good carbornation and body. Good beer.

UPDATED: AUG 27, 2011 Bottled. Thx to doodler. Murky amber coloured. Small light beige head. Light sweetness, berries, light vinegar, spice in the aroma. Intense, vinegar, grape, berries and spice. Very wellmade and balanced. Medium to full bodied. Ends on a nice sourish berry note. Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle.  Hazy copper with a small white head.  Slightly acetic, some sweetness, and oak?  Taste is sour, some astringency, lemon.  Good shit.  Quick rating before my buddys wedding.

375 ml bottle from fbm115.  thanks man!  This is my bottle of beer to celebrate finishing the bar exam.  Reddish pour with a muddy tint, lots of bubbles clinging to the side of the glass, no head.  Aroma of cherries, strong tartness, mild apple cider vinegar.  Strong oak and mild fruitiness are with the aroma.  Flavor is strongly sour.  Quite tart, actually.  Lots of cherries, oak, wet wool, Vinuous notes, mild vinnegar.  Pretty stunning sour.  Fair carbonation over a full mouthfeel.  Finishes long and sour.  Excellent, actually.

UPDATED: AUG 9, 2011 Batch 3. Beautiful hazy rosy coppery-gold with pale red highlights and a quickly-dissipating very fine off-white head. Fine strands of tiny bubbles gracefully stream up from the bottom of the glass. A deep, piercingly sour aroma tickles the nose at first and leads into a background of soft spice while expressing a hair-raising lactic sour verve. Vibrant vinous fruitiness is intermingled with soft oak and barrel oxidation and a pleasant solvency only deepens the complexity. Taste bud-cramping sourness on the attack clears to reveal a multi-layered dark grapey fruitiness and an uncanny wine-like complexity. Alcohol rises in the back-end with deeply complex fermentation notes and a very slight spicy bitterness with a hint of light, nutty malt. The body is light but its nimble presence in the mouth conveys significant strength. The finish goes on and on as it slowly unfolds a profound complexity across the palate. This is truly a perfect hybrid drinking experience between beer and wine. Quite amazing.

[3821-20110710] 375mL bottle. Woody sour cask aroma. Murky, orange red body with no lasting head. Deliciously sour fruity flavour is bold and balanced. Medium body is quite sour. Wonderful brew, could sip a lot of this over an evening. (8/3/8/4/17) 4.0
(w/ jerc, others; jercs 5000th marker!)

Bottle batch 3.  Murky reddish brown pour with a off white head.  Mild stone fruits, apples, oak, and vanilla aromas.  Score, the first beer from Captain Lawrence that has not severely disappointed.  Crisp and refreshing with a somewhat dry finish.  Great cabernet grape, oak, vanilla, and caramel malt flavors.  Im impressed......

Bottle (375ml) shared with friends c/o jerc. Pours a murky orange-amber with no head. Awesome sour aroma, lots of tart berries and very citrusy along with some light spices, a hint of vinegar and wood. Flavour: Holy moly, thats tart! Puckeringly tart! It follows the aroma but Its not refreshing, its acidic and its almost too tart -- almost. Average bodied. I really like it but a small serving of this will do.
sample courtesy of Jerc. somewhat murky reddish amber pour. cherry tartness, quite acidic, extremely tart. funky earthiness. quite tasty and very much appreciated Jeremy

Shared by jerc - his 5,000th rating!!!!  My notes are sadly minimal, frankly I was already pretty drunk.  Lovely ruby colour, minimal off-white head, simple and appealing aroma of sour cherries and light dry oak tannin - taste followed, hard to judge the alcohol, but it was "real" cherry and REAL sour, some sweet maltiness to balance, just fun to drink.  Syrupy, decently carbonated, naturally the mouthfeel was acidic - left a nice tart cherry tingle behind.  Splendid!!

2011-07-10. Hazy red amber body, with a small beige head. Woody lightly funky aroma. Light lactic note, and muted cherry fruit. 7+ Flavour is modestly sour and acidic throughout, fair amount of woody oak in the overtones.  Cherry character is modest but present throughout. 7+ Average bodied palate suits the beer nicely and has a pleasant carbonation to it. Could be zippier at times but this is just a very drinkable beer. Lovely.  My 5000th Rating, Graciously provided by Rciesla

Batch 2. The cap was beginning to show signs of rust. Removal produces a nice pop and then....gusher. It was a slow gush, but it still stirred up the beer enough to allow all the bottom sediment to circulate around. As the foam was coming up and over I poured an inch or so into the glass. I noticed some nice red phloem chunks floating around, so the rest of the beer was poured through a strainer. Using a palm tulip for this.  A - Deep brownish red. Quite cloudy due to the circulation. There was obviously a ton of foam, but it all died down nicely to a one finger spotty off-white head which eventually turned into some nice lacing around the edges. S - Oak, vanilla, grapes, and vinegar. This smell is great, but not as complex as the flavor profile. T - Tart grape juice. Lots of oak which provides a ton of dry wood and vanilla flavors. Vinegar and some light brett funk, finished up with just a hint of booze. Rather complex and very delicious. O - Wow! I love this beer. Im a big fan of flanders and oud bruins. This is just amazing. Extremely well made American wild.

Bottle at Stone sour ale fest.  Orange brown pour, with a quickly diminishing fizzy head.  Sweet grapes, brett funk, acidic, oak, fruit, and mild grassiness.  A very clean, professional tasting sour.  Well done.

Bottle. Pour is a murky brown with little head and aromas of oak, sour  funkiness and white grapes. Flavor is a swirling mix of white grapes, sour cherries and oak. Good stuff and thanks coyotehunter!
user_location: The Wet Side of a Dry Town, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Sampled from the bottle share at Clusterfork in Placentia. Slight reddish in color. Very smooth on your palate with a smooth tart, sour presence. Flavors and interesting and excellent. Cherry, grape, peach along with the bret funk. Really tasty beer and would love to get a hold of a bottle for sure.

This poured a darker orange color, a bit cloudy, with off white head. Aroma was very vienous, lots of grape skins, vinegar, and funk, interesting. Flavor was very tart, but not mouth puckering, more like sour fruit than funk, white whine like.

Head gone in secs, over lively carbonated, hazed brown-red beer. End of bottle solid yeast. Bretts, lactic acid, citrus, saddlesoap and red fruit, including grapes. Red fruit, grapes, citrus and the classical background Brett - and at least, none of the floormop variety. Rather thick, slick to viscous MF, carbonation much less obvious in the mouth. Oh, yes, Americans are closing very much into the real lambics. Very good, obviously, but less easily drinkable than my usual kriekenlambics. Txs to Ryan & Victor
Batch 3 bottle shared by Dmac at RBSG. Pours light mahogany. Nose/taste of sour apple, red grapes, vinegar, cherry wood and oak. Woody tart complexity. Good balance. Not overpowering.

Bottle thanks to dmac.  Dirty apple juice colored pour, very little head, lasting carbonation and a wonderful sour apple aroma.  Flavor is  also dry woody apple a little tart cherry and a cheesy/fruity sour aftertaste.  Solid beer and definitely worth tracking down.

Batch #3. Poured into a tulip.

3.5 A: Opaque amber grape color. Between two and three fingers of beige fizzy soda pop head falls almost as quickly as it was formed despite a steady stream of bubbles and leaves no lacing.

4.0 S: Big time grape/vinous character. Super tart with lactic sourness as well. Also a lot of musty, musky funk. Supple tannins give a light astringent. Cherry is second to grape and is accompanied by oak and a light vanilla. Complex and pleasant.

4.5 T: Taste is much like the nose, but for whatever reason, it is more impressive. Anyway, tart grape and cherry with some lactic sourness, but not quite mouth puckering. Instead, the sourness level allows for this beer to be wonderfully well balanced. Quite fruity overall with some plum underneath the cherry and grape. Surprisingly, the cherry is stronger than the grape. Toasty malts in the middle with light caramel notes. The finish is woody and astringent with a lot of the brett funkiness coming into play.

4.5 M: Medium body. Good moderate carbonation. Incredibly creamy, like the head on a cappucino.

4.5 D: This is a very good beer. Until now, Ive never really been impressed by CL. Complex throughout with great flavors and a killer mouthfeel.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 05-30-2011 22:28:21

Bottle. Pours an unclear and reddish brown beer with a weak offwhite head. The aroma is malt, acidity and fruit. The flavor is following the nose with additional tart. The palate is acidic. Overall a good beer.
Trade from rgtravers, thanks man. Bottle @ Odense tasting. Mud reddish body with a small white head. Aroma is berries, brett, sour notes and wood. Flavor is sour berries, immature pine and wood.

Draft at Rattle n Hum during the Sours Gone Wild Event with Pat, Dallas, Bobby and Andrew. Pours a hazy, amber body with white lacing. Aroma is funky, fruity, and dusty. Mouthfeel is sour and carbonated with notes of tart fruit, funk and yeast. Great sour!
Pours copper with a beige head. Aroma is caramel, sour, acidic, brett, acetone, fruity notes and redwine. Flavour is caramel, heavy acidic, redwine, light fruit, plum, acetone and brett.
At rattle n hum during beers gone wild.  A balanced not overly vinegary sour ale.  Has a grape, sangria type feel.
Cloudy red amber with a small white head. Aroma of berries, wood and brett, with an unfortunate (though small) hint of acetone. Dry and acidic flavour with a note not unlike unripe pineapples.

Batch 1 enjoyed in Spring 2011
Appearance:  Pours a dark dull maroon with no head and a micro tan stripe around the top of the beer.

Aroma: Funky oak barrel, red grape skin.

Taste: Soft wine barrel, tart red fruit, funky buggy yeast. Finishes sour and tannic.

Mouthfeel: Full bodied, chunky, astringent.

Overall:  A really great sour, Id like to snag more of this.

Bottle @ Odense Tasting, May 2011. Thanks Jacob - Hallinghansen. Pours uunclear amber/red with a small off white head. Brett, berries and acetone. Flavor is very sour - grapes, oak and brett. Prickles the tongue. Tasty stuff.

Courtesy of craftycarl21! Brownish pour with a small fizzy champagne like head. The aroma holds big vinous barrel, bubblegum, lots of lacto sourness, some acetic acid, and funky oak. THe flavor holds bretty funk with big dark fruit port notes that culminate with oaky barrel. Medium bodied mouthfeel with excellent prickling carbonation. What a treat....

Rating #1000. Huge thanks to vtafro for sending me this one for the occasion. 375 mL bottle, batch 3 from last weekends release. Muddy brown pour that nearly fizzed out of the bottle. The head dies quickly, but livens up with a swirl beautifully. First whiff of the aroma gave of huge red wine and barrel tones, and that was just while pouring. Once I really got my nose in there the nose progresses to monstrous oak, lemon, Bretty funk, barnyard, and some nice vinous sour grape, cherry and bubblegum undertones. Flavor brings tons more barrel, with big woody oak and vanilla tannin presence. Bretty funk takes a back seat, but is still present at just the right level. More vinous booze, almost at the sherry or port level. Mouthfeel is much less acidic than I expected, but its really beautiful, with the barrel and sweet wine presence really toning things down exceptionally well; a wondrously drinkable sour. Truly lovely.

375ml bottle from batch #2.  Pours light reddish-brown, with unimpressive head that rapidly dissipates.  Aroma is of vinegar, red wine, oak and some funk.  Taste is amazing, tart and tangy with strong sour notes.  Tart finish, with lingering flavors.  This is a nice American sour ale.  Well done!

Hazy amber pour light off white head ... aroma of sour brett, wine and oak .... taste is sour brett and oaky red wine with a sweet grape and berry very well balanced ..... tart and dry mouthfeel ....  oaky dry sour finish .... an amazing brew thanks victor for sharing!!

(375ml bottle courtesy of zestar!!). Pours a cloudy red-brown color with thin off-white head.  Aroma is funky with some basement and hints of some fruit.  The aroma is definitely more like a Belgian sour rather than an American one.  Taste is tart, but it has some vinegar, again more like a Belgian.  Medium bodied with an oily texture.  Dry finish.  This is an awesome beer that seems to be a perfect hybrid of the vinegary, funky belgians and the fuller-bodied American versions.  Really nice job!

375 ml bottle batch #2 shared by pineypower at the UFC FIght Night, thanks Dean. Poured a reddish/brown body with a super small almost nonexistant head. Aroma of super sour cherries, vinegar, slight wood. Medium bodied and despite the nonexistant head this one had stronger carbonation once it passed your lips. Flavor of just tons and tons of sourness and vinegar with hint of cherry. Awesome stuff and Im not even reallt a sourhead.

Shared with a few good friends in the midst of a casual sour tasting. Pours a reddish color. Aroma on this is fantastic, exploding with cherries and tart. The flavor brought too much acetic for me to be able to truly enjoy the complexities of this beer. The apparent crystal sweetness didnt work with the sour.  While those of us at the tasting all gravitate towards a more lactic sour, we all agreed that there was just too much vinegar to enjoy this one.

Courtesy of a generous trader, batch #1Muddy dark amber color; small head.Very interesting aroma, malty, a bit sour, vinous, Bretts, light cookies, very light bread, chocolate and dust, very light alcohol; the elements are all well blended, creating both harmony and complexity.Smooth mouthfeel, good body; strong acidity, malt flavor, evident wine character; good tannic and astringent final, with a pleasant and subtle lemon touch.Great.
Draft. Pours reddish with a thin head. Acetic and woody aroma with fruity rhubarb-like notes. Awesome sour/tart flavor, with woody notes, fruity wine like notes, and strawberry rhubarb. Great stuff.

Was going through my backlog and wanted to find something kind of special for #500, then had this today and figured it would be tough to top.
On tap at Blind Tiger. Pours hazy light brown with no real head. Aroma is very nice, sour with lots of fruit, cherries, funky, a bit of vinegar. Taste starts out with a faint fruity sweetness up front but then gives way to a tart sourness that takes over. Oak really comes out on the finish. Quite a delicious brew, I look forward to enjoying this one again.
Tap at blind tiger. Light, tart acidic and vinegary. This is light brown and very sour. Just fabuous. Glad i skipped out of work to try it

UPDATED: JUL 7, 2011 12.7oz bottle into my Narke tulip, batch 1. Thanks to my girlfriend for this birthday present...Pours a medium dirty, light tan head, ok retention, light lacing...Aroma is dominated by funkiness, oak, light vinegar, and a little red wine on the finish. Oak is the backbone, balanced and complex, could be a tad more tart. Smells is a little like consecreation mainly because of the oak...The taste is is very oaky, like the aroma is the backbone of the beer peaking out at all corners. Tart to start, a very sharp bite, but then it fades pretty quickly to light chalk, vinegar, and a tannic red wine finish. The feel is nice, very coated and full...Easy to drink oud bruin, light tartness, could be a little more tart a still drinkable.

An above average oud bruin, very drinkable, nice wine flavors, nice wine flavors, light tartness, more could show

Re-review of batch 3 - the nose is much sharper, a ton more vinegar and acidity.  The taste has lots of oak, isnt as acidic and comes off a bit chemically.  Rated batch 1 a 3.8.

Batch 1. Big thanks to Brad for the bottle - this one was a treat to try. Apparently Captain Lawrence really, really didnt want the bottle opened too soon - trying to force the wax off the top actually broke my bottle opener in half. After winning the battle (I pulled out a ViseGrip), this brew poured a murky brownish amber, with only a tiny bit of carbonation left. Nose is cherries, oak, dry merlot, tons of funk, some raspberry, and some underlying vanilla. Flavor starts out sweet and fruity, almost immediately building a sour zing, Both sides of the flavor attack your palate with reckless abandon, building to a crescendo and then leaving your mouth whimpering in the aftermath. Super complex - theyre right about that - and interesting in that despite the lack of carbonation, it still feels tingly/prickly. The sour quality in here actually takes the place of the carbonation, a la Cantillon. I thought it was a bit too oaky/funky at first, but its really grown on me throughout the glass. Im a fan.

Thanks Kevin for sharing this! Batch #2 from the recent release.

A-pours a brownish copper color with notes of orange edges. The head is off white and creamy looking. Bubbles reside on top

S-the nose is quite nice with white grapes and a nice tartness touching the nose first. A nice oaky wood aroma and a touch of vanilla come in next, hints of sawdust underneath with a light sweetness and a touch of funk in the back

T-A tart but sweet note of grape comes in first. Earthy malts and the taste of musk fades in after the initial sweetness. The finish adds some cherries with some light vinigar acidity

M-the feel is great, full bodied, soft and creamy on the palate. The body holds through the entire drink coating the mouth. The finish is slightly prickly on the back of the throat.

D-This is a very good beer with a nice level of complexity. Tart and sweet with a touch of funk and a terrific feel.

375ml Bottle.  Batch 2.  A big thanks to peteinSD for sharing this one!  Should start by saying that this is one of the best sours anywhere and totally blew me away.  Had a deep murky brick color in the glass with a tiny layer of white bubbles.  Nose was powerful with some potent funk and a nice layer of sweet red wine grapes.  Exceedingly intricate flavor profile with strong tart notes, dry red wine barrel character and a bit of detectable sweetness that reminds me of brown ale which I think is the base for this one.  The tartness is bright and has a bit of grape and green apple character.  Brett is noticeable in the aroma, but also seems to take the edge off the strong lacto presence by contributing that odd barnyard and stale cheese note.  The palate is medium light with a soft carbonation and the balance of the sour character is outstanding.  I could seriously drink this beer all day with no drop off in enjoyment.  This one was good enough that it is painful to think about the fact that I may never get my hands on it again.  A definite winner.

UPDATED: FEB 18, 2011 Bottle courtesy Dyan - thank you!  Batch 2.  Murky red wine, off-brown in the glass with light carbonation.  Aroma is tight Flanders red, sour, juicy muscat grapes, and light tart.  Precise, integrated aroma.  Taste is sweet white wine grapes, sour, and an amazing burning tart finish.  Probably the most well-balanced sour I have ever enjoyed.  Extraordinary.

Bottle.
Pours red mahogny without any head.
Pleasant taste of strawberries and earthy wine. The sourness is rather kind, lik swedish vinegar chips (as in not going all the way)
Bottle. This is a great sour ale for beginners. Its not overly sour, and it has got a lot of sweet qualities that reminds me of strawberries (seeds) and a easy to drink (earthy) red wine. Nice.

Batch 2. Received in a trade with koopa. Thanks again Dennis!

Pours a very dark ruby red color with dark mahogany edges when held to a light source and a one finger off white head that quickly settles into a lasting ring.

Funky, musty aroma with prominent earthy oak along with some vanilla, brett effervescence and vinous dark fruit. Captain Lawrence does a good job of replicating the funk from Belgian lambics really well in their sours and this one is no exception. A lot of the American Wild Ales Ive encountered recently are overpowered by a dry brett character but this one has a musty, earthy, barnyard/horsey presence to it. Thats not to say that its as intense as a Belgian sour but its there. Theres also a subtle vinegar presence and a very strong vinous dark fruit/red wine character. Lots of grape, tart dark cherry, currant and other berries.

Tart, puckering medium body that is pretty sour and slightly acidic but this is countered by the sweet vinous dark fruit notes, earthy oak, lacto, dry brett and subtle vanilla. This beer starts off pretty tart with a puckering sourness that lingers throughout. Again, there is some nice earthy/musty barnyard funk going on in addition to the dry brett presence. The funk is complimented by the dry brett and earthy oak. Theres a very prominent sweet, vinous dark fruit presence mid-palate that balances things out. Hints of grape, tart dark cherries, currant, plum and other dark berries. The label says that fresh red grapes are added but I wouldnt be surprised if this was aged in a red wine barrel. The sweetness from the grapes is excellently compliment by the lingering vinegary puckering character in the dry finish. As soon as I put the glass down Im salivating for more. There is some slight acidity but this beer is incredibly quaffable.

This is the best sour Ive had from Captain Lawrence so far and one of the better American Wild Ales Ive had in a while.

Huge thanks to Nick for breaking this one out.  Bottle pours burnt red with a white head.  Aroma shows apples, grapes, caramel, raspberry vinagerette, and a touch of funk.  Flavor shows the same with additional dark cherry notes from time to time.  Overall body is moderate and creamy, with moderate acidity.

375ml batch 2 opened at my new years beer bash. Pours hazy light red with short lasting white head. aroma is very acidic and vinegar like with earthy grapes and sweetness. Drinks very tart and clean with tons of fruit and tannins. Sweet body around the tartness with a touch of oak. Finishes lightly dry with grapes and vinegar on the palate.

12.7oz bottle. Batch #1. Poured a medium and slightly hazy mahogany color with a very small sized head. Cloudier towards the bottom of the bottle. Aromas of grapes, lighter vinegar, woody, vinous, and a little funky. Woodiness came out more and more.Tastes of grapes, the same lighter vinegar, vinous, cherries, wood, and some funkiness. Sweet and tart.

Batch 2. 2009. Shared with a local BA on 09.23.2010.

Pours a hazy carmine, with a small amount of head moving wistfully about in the glass, like a Rorschach blot. It leaves me thinking about tomato juice.

Smells of musk, Brett, tart red grapes, and fresh, dry oak. A small amount of earthiness (geosmin) comes through, as well. Quite tannic in the mouth, with, unsurprisingly, quite a lot of vinousness. Dry, with some pucker. The nose is juicier than the taste, but this is still a nice combination red grape, cranberry, oak, and earthy spiciness. 

Clean and dry, with medium-low carbonation. A treat, but not exactly my cup of tea.

The aroma is brett, tart fruit.  The appearance is a cloudy red color, white head.  The flavor is sour, vinegar, cherries, grapes.  The finish is acidic, sour.  Medium, medium/thin body.  Very enjoyable sour.

Tasted on 12/19/10 from a 500mL bottle with the AZ crew, Batch 1.  Thank you so much Nick for busting this one out.  Pours cloudy brown-orange with only a white lace collar.  The nose is sour and funky with apple cider, vinegar, and just a hint of caramel malt.  The flavor is sour apple cider vinegar, a bunch of lemon (both zest and juice), and a very tannic feel.  The body is medium with a sticky texture, light carbonation and a long sour and tannic finish.

Thanks Avalon68!  Batch 2.  Strongly tart, grape skin, some peach, little brett.  Auburn brown, hazy and murky and a pale sandy head.  Oaky brown base, excellent grape middle, little magic marker bites quickly, sublime syrah wine barrel in the finish.  And to think this was a bonus!

A: The pour is a dark amber color thats perhaps a bit more on the brown side. The head is off-white in color.

S: The nose starts off with sweet malts, cherries, and red grapes. Red wine vinegar becomes very apparent quite quickly and is followed up by an unfortunate amount of butter.

T: Very heavy on the vinegar which provides a big sourness right off the bat. Unfortunately, lots of metallic and buttery flavors that just ruin this beer.

M: The body is medium and the carbonation is light to medium. Grape? skins provide a bit of a chewiness...

D: I remember having a bottle of the first batch and thinking it was pretty good. However, this one didnt quite live up to that experience.

Picked up this bottle of Batch 2 at the release on 03.27.2010.

A: Pours a somewhat-hazed ruby with a tight white head and a tiny bit of lacing.

S: Sour notes come out alongside earth, oak, yeast, a bit of anise, and a bit of red wine.

T: Very similar with some cherries coming in as well. Good grape flavor, and a bit of the anise shining through. Quite tasty, but not as complex as I was hoping it would be. 

M: Medium bodied with a moderate amount of dryness. Good sourness and carbonation.

D: Enough complexity to keep me finding new things, but nothing really tying everything together. A very good beer that Im glad I got, but not the best that Ive had.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 04-03-2010

Bottle, Batch 2, shared by badnewsbeers. Hazy deep orange-red body, thin ring and islands of buff carbonation. Sweet, slightly tart nose dominated by pineapple juice and grape. Sweet to tart body featuring primarily pineapple juice and brown sugar, with some prickly alcohol heat and a bitter finish. An interesting beer, not quite as good as Cuvee de Castleton, but delicious nonetheless.

Bottle at Where the Wild Beers Are. Pours the shade of iced tea. Really cool aroma of anise, red cherry, and strawberry. Extremely tart with some dark plum notes. Awesomely tannic and oaky with sharp acetone. Really nice lingering tartness. Great stuff.

Bottle shared by footbalm at Jordans. This one crept up on me, little expectation plus great beer equals awesome! Pours a dark copper color with a medium white head. The aroma is sour grapes, woody tannin,funk. A wonderful vinous flavor, I even had a grape peel in my glass, acetic, barrels, funky and dry, but dominated by a wonderful sour grape. Lovely.

Bottle: Pours a nice dark mahogany redish color with a puffy sparse head. The nose is full and fruity, lots of full fruity character and a nice tart accent. Just about right for the tartness vs. sweet. The flavor is funk and fruit, but in a nice harmony with some light cheese and barny notes. Straw and hay, some leather and banana too. Very complex and delicious. Sour and very quaffable.

A GIFT from levifunk. Not part of a trade. Given to me as a gift! Love it. Batch 2. Bottle. Reddish purple pour with minimal head. Aroma of sour funk, oak, grape, and citrus.  Flavor of grape, bread, sugar, milky yeast, and caramel. Very bizarre. Sour as hell either way. And good. I must say that this is quite inferior to CdC though.

Big thanks to Exiled for sharing this bottle, which was drank alongside Cuvee de Castleton, Barrel Select and Flaming Fury. 

The beer pours an amber-red color with a white head. The aroma is very nice. I get some licorice and tart dark fruit. The flavor is sour cherries, licorice, sour grapes, oak and some brown sugar that adds just a little bit of sweetness to the beer. Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation. A very nice American-made sour beer.

Bottle: Poured a murky brown/red color ale with a small foamy head with minimal retention. Aroma of weird funk is quite powerful with some sour and oak notes also noticeable. Taste is also overpowered by the weird funk notes which didnt agree with me (I usually did the barnyard notes but those were too much) and a sour lightly acidic finish. Body was quite full with medium carbonation. I had a hard time getting into this one  probably one of the worst from a usually excellent brewer.

Brought a batch 1 & 2 for a side by side at Andres tasting party. While this rating is for Batch 1 - both were great.  375 bottle pours a reddish-brown with a nice beige-white head, well-carbed and had a nice sour nose. Loved the funk flavors and wine characters on the palate - with plenty of fruit, caramel, cider and a slight vinegar tartness on the finish.  While both versions were outstanding , the aging helped mellow the edges of this sour down and brought out the big fruit. Thanks CL.... Keep em coming...
bottle shared at RBSG10 grand tasting - orange pour, lemony, cherry tart fruits with a touch of spice and caramel malts. Tasty, but a bit too acetic for my tastes

Batch 2, my Kovy signed in NJ/Memorial day beer. Pours out a ruby hued brown color with a moderate beige head. Aroma is tart with sour, vinous notes, light wood, some sweet fruit preserves and grape juice. Flavor its very complex, some nice sour notes, tartness, oak, sweet fruit juice. Everything comes together very well with nothing dominating too much, finishes with a nice tart/sour taste with slight notes of grape sweetness. Definitely need to try this with some age on it, but world class right now.
The aroma is slightly sweet with tons of funk. The color is murky amber with a small head. The flavor is sharp tart with a nice bite at the end that manages to be smooth and rich on the palate.
